Compute the flux of the vector field \vec F = 9 x^2y^2z\vec k through the surface S which is the cone \sqrt{x^2+y^2}=z, with 0\le z\le R, oriented downward.
(a) Parameterize the cone using cylindrical coordinates (write \theta as theta).
with \le r\le
and \le \theta \le
(b) With this parameterization, what is d\vec A?
d\vec A =
(c) Find the flux of \vec F through S.
flux =

static.solution:
S is parameterized by \vec r(r,\theta)=r\cos \theta\vec i+r\sin \theta\vec j+r\vec k, with 0\le r\le R and 0\le\theta\le 2\pi. We have \frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial r}\times \frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial \theta} = \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \vec i \amp \vec j \amp \vec k\\ \cos{\theta} \amp \sin{\theta} \amp 1 \\ -r\sin{\theta} \amp r\cos{\theta} \amp 0 \end{array}\right| = - r \cos\theta \vec i - r \sin \theta \vec j + r \vec k. Since the vector \partial \vec r / \partial r \times \partial \vec r / \partial \theta points upward, in the direction opposite to the specified orientation, we use d\vec A= -\left(\partial\vec r/\partial r\times\partial\vec r/\partial\theta\right) \,dr\,d\theta = (r\cos\theta\vec i + r\sin\theta\vec j - r\vec k)\, dr\,d\theta\,.
Hence \int_S\vec F\cdot d\vec A = \int_0^{2\pi}\!\int_0^R 9 (r^5 \cos^2\theta\sin^2\theta\vec k)\cdot (r \cos\theta \vec i + r \sin \theta \vec j - r \vec k)\,dr\,d\theta = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^{R} -9 r^6\cos^2{\theta}\sin^2{\theta}\,dr\,d\theta = -\frac{9 R^7}{7}\int_0^{2\pi} \sin^2{\theta}\cos^2{\theta}\, d\theta = -\frac{9 R^7}{7}\int_0^{2\pi} \sin^2{\theta}(1-\sin^2{\theta})\, d\theta = -\frac{ 9 R^7}{7}\int_0^{2\pi} (\sin^2{\theta}-\sin^4{\theta})\, d\theta = -\left(\frac{9 R^7}{7}\right)\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)= -\frac{9}{28} \pi R^7.
The cone is not differentiable at the point (0,0). However the flux integral, which is improper, converges.

statement.p: Compute the flux of the vector field \vec F = z\vec i + 8 x\vec j through the parameterized surface S oriented upward and given, for 0\le s\le 1, \ \ 2\le t\le 4, by x=s^2, \quad y=2s+t^2, \quad z=3 t.
flux =

static.solution:
\partial \vec r / \partial s \times \partial \vec r / \partial t is given by \frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial s}\times\frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial t}= \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \quad\vec i\quad\amp \quad\vec j\quad\amp \quad\vec k\quad\\ 2s \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2t \amp 3 \end{array} \right| = 6\vec i- 6 s\vec j+4st\vec k. Since the z-component, 4st, of the vector \partial \vec r / \partial s \times \partial \vec r / \partial t is positive for 0 \lt s \leq 1, 2 \leq t \leq 4, we see that \partial \vec r/\partial s \times \partial \vec r / \partial t points upward, in the direction of the orientation of S we were given.
Thus, we use d\vec A = \left(\frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial s} \times \frac{\partial \vec r}{\partial t}\right)\,ds\,dt, and so we have \int_S\vec F\cdot d\vec A = \int_0^{1}\int_{2}^{4} (3 t\vec i + 8 s^2\vec j)\cdot (6\vec i- 6 s\vec j+4st\vec k)\,dt\,ds =\int_0^{1}\int_{2}^{4} (18 t - 48 s^3)\,dt\,ds = \int_0^{1}(9 t^2 - 48 s^3 t)\bigg|_{t=2}^{t=4}\,ds =\int_0^{1}(108 - 96 s^3)\,ds=(108s - 24 s^4)\bigg|_0^{1} =84.

statement.p: Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: If S is the cube bounded by the six planes x = \pm 3, y = \pm 3, z = \pm 3, oriented outward, and \vec{F} = 2 \vec{i} - \vec{k}, then the flux of \vec{F} through S is zero.

If S is the unit sphere centered at the origin, oriented outward and \vec{F} = x \vec{i} + y \vec{j} + z\vec{k} = \vec{r}, then the flux integral \displaystyle \iint_S \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{A} is positive.
If S is an open-ended circular cylinder centered about the z-axis, oriented away from the z-axis, and \vec{F} = \langle 3,-2,6 \rangle, then the flux of \vec{F} through S is zero.

If S is the unit sphere centered at the origin, oriented outward and the flux integral \displaystyle \iint_S \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{A} is zero, then \vec{F}(x,y,z) is perpendicular to \vec{r} = \langle x,y,z \rangle at every point of S.
The area vector of a flat, oriented surface is parallel to the surface.
If S is an open-ended circular cylinder centered about the z-axis, oriented away from the z-axis, and \vec{F} = \langle x,y,0 \rangle, then the flux of \vec{F} through S is positive.
If S is the unit sphere centered at the origin, oriented outward and the flux integral \displaystyle \iint_S \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{A} is zero, then \vec{F} = \vec{0}.

statement.p: Let \mathcal{S} be the square in the xy-plane shown in the figure below, oriented with the normal pointing in the positive z-direction. Estimate \iint_{\mathcal{S}} \mathbf{F} \cdot \,d\mathbf{S} where \mathbf{F} is a vector field whose values at the labeled points are \begin{array}{llll} \mathbf{F}(A) \amp = \left\lt -5,3,2\right>,\amp \qquad \mathbf{F}(B) \amp = \left\lt 1,7,7\right>\\ \mathbf{F}(C) \amp = \left\lt -9,4,-6\right>,\amp \qquad \mathbf{F}(D) \amp = \left\lt -1,-4,-8\right>\end{array}

static.solution:
S is = \left\lt 0,0,1\right>.
We estimate the vector surface integral \iint_S \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} using the division and sample points given in the Figure.
Each subsquare has area \frac14, therefore we obtain the following estimation: \iint_S \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} \approx \left(\mathbf{F} (A)\cdot {\mathbf{e}}_n + \mathbf{F} (B) \cdot {\mathbf{e}}_n +\mathbf{F} (C) \cdot {\mathbf{e}}_n + \mathbf{F} (D) \cdot {\mathbf{e}}_n\right) \cdot \frac14 = (\left\lt -5,3,2\right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,1\right>+\left\lt 1,7,7\right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,1\right>+\left\lt -9,4,-6\right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,1\right>+\left\lt -1,-4,-8\right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,1\right>) \cdot \frac14 = (2+7 - 6 - 8) \cdot \frac14=-1.25

statement.p: F = x\boldsymbol{i}+y\boldsymbol{j}+2z\boldsymbol{k} and \sigma is the portion of the cone z = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} between the planes z = 2 and z = 5 oriented with normal vectors pointing upwards. Find the flux of the flow field F across \sigma:
Show that \Phi(u,v)= (5 u+9 ,u-v,9 u+v) parametrizes the plane 2x-y-z=18. Then:
(a) Calculate {\mathbf{T}}_u , {\mathbf{T}}_v, and {\mathbf{n}}(u,v).
(b) Find the area of \mathcal{S}=\Phi(\mathcal{D}), where \mathcal{D}= (u,v) : 0\le u\le 5, 0\le v \le 2.
(c) Express f(x,y,z)=yz in terms of u and v and evaluate \iint_{\mathcal{S}} f(x,y,z)\,d \mathcal{S}.
(a) {\mathbf{T}}_u= , {\mathbf{T}}_v= , {\mathbf{n}}(u,v)=

static.solution:
x=5 u+9, y=u-v, and z=9 u+v satisfy the equation of the plane, 2x-y-z =2(5 u+9 )-( u-v )-( 9 u+v )=10 u+18-u+v-9 u-v=18 Moreover, for any x, y, z satisfying 2x-y-z=18,
there are values of u and v such that x=5 u+9,
y=u-v, and z=9 u+v, since the following equations can be solved for u and v: \begin{array}{rcl}x\amp {}={}\amp 5 u+9\\ \noalign{\smallskip} y\amp =\amp u-v\\ \noalign{\smallskip} z\amp =\amp 9 u+v\\ \noalign{\smallskip} 2x-y-z\amp =\amp 18\end{array}\quad\Rightarrow\quad u=\frac{x-9}{5},\quad v=\frac{x-9}{5}-y We conclude that \mathrm{\Phi }( u,v ) parametrizes the whole plane 2x-y-z=18.
(a) The tangent vectors {\mathbf{T} }_u and {\mathbf{T} }_v are: {\mathbf{T} }_u =\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial u}=\frac{\partial }{\partial u}( 5 u+9,u-v,9 u+v )= \left\lt 5,1,9 \right>{\mathbf{T} }_v =\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial v}=\frac{\partial }{\partial v}( 5 u+9,u-v,9 u+v )= \left\lt 0,-1,1 \right> The normal vector is the following cross product: \mathbf{n} ( u,v )={\mathbf{T} }_u \times {\mathbf{T} }_v = \left|\begin{array}{rrr}\mathbf{i} \amp \mathbf{j} \amp \mathbf{k} \\ 5\amp 1\amp 9\\ 0\amp -1\amp 1\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{rr}1\amp 9\\ -1\amp 1\end{array}\right|\mathbf{i} -\left|\begin{array}{rr}5\amp 9\\ 0\amp 1\end{array}\right|\mathbf{j} +\left|\begin{array}{rr}5\amp 1\\ 0\amp -1\end{array}\right|\mathbf{k}= 10 \mathbf{i} -5 \mathbf{j} -5 \mathbf{k} = \left\lt 10,-5,-5 \right> (b) That area of S=\mathrm{\Phi }(\mathcal{D}) is the following surface integral: Area(S)=\iint_{\mathcal{D}} \| \mathbf{n} ( u,v )\| \,du \,dv=\iint_{\mathcal{D}} \| \left\lt 10,-5,-5 \right>\| \,du \,dv= 5\sqrt{6}\iint_{\mathcal{D}} 1 \,du \,dv=
5\sqrt{6}\, \mathrm{Area} (\mathcal{D}) =5\sqrt{6}\cdot 5\cdot 2=50 \sqrt{6} (c) We express f( x,y,z )=yz in terms of the parameters u and v: f\left(\phi ( u,v )\right)=( u-v )(9 u+v )=9 u^2-8 uv- v^2 Using the Theorem on Surface Integrals we have: \iint_S f( x,y,z ) \,dS = \iint_{\mathcal{D}}f\left(\phi ( u,v )\right)\| \mathbf{n} ( u,v )\| \,du \,dv=\iint_{\mathcal{D}} \left(9 u^2-8uv- v^2\right)\| \left\lt 10,-5,-5 \right>\| \,du \,dv= 5\sqrt{6}\int_0^{2} \int_0^{5} \left(9 u^2-8uv- v^2\right) \,du \,dv=5\sqrt{6}\int_0^{2} \left( \frac{9 u^3}3 -\frac{8u^2v}2- v^2u\right)\bigg|_{u=0}^{5} \,dv= 5\sqrt{6}\int_0^{2} \left(\frac{1125}3-\frac{200v}2-5 v^2\right) \,dv =5\sqrt{6}\left(\frac{1125v}3-\frac{200v^2}4-\frac{5 v^3}3 \right)\bigg|_0^{2} =\frac{32200\sqrt{6}}{12}\approx 6572.8

statement.p: Calculate \iint_{\mathcal{S}} f(x,y,z)\,dS For y = 5-z^2 \text{,} \qquad 0\le x, z\le 8 \text{;}\qquad f(x,y,z)=z \iint_{\mathcal{S}} f(x,y,z)\,dS=

static.solution: y=g( x,z ): \iint_S f( x,y,z ) \,dS=\iint_{\mathcal{D}} f\left(x,g( x,z ),z\right)\sqrt{1+ g_x^2+ g_z^2} \,dx \,dz \quad \mathbf{(1)} Since y=g( x,z )=5- z^2, we have g_x =0, g_z =-2z, hence: \sqrt{1+ g_x^2+ g_z^2}=\sqrt{1+4 z^2}f\left(x,g( x,z ),z\right)=z The domain of integration is the square \left[0,8\right]\times \left[0,8\right] in the xz-plane. By \mathbf{(1)} we get: \iint_S f( x,y,z ) \,dS = \int_0^{8} \int_0^{8} z\sqrt{1+4 z^2} \,dz \,dx=\left(\int_0^{8} 1 \,dx\right)\left(\int_0^{8} z \sqrt{1+4 z^2} \,dz\right)=8\int_0^{8} z \sqrt{1+4 z^2} \,dz We use the substitution u={1+4 z^2}, \,du= 8z \,dz to compute the integral. This gives: \iint_S f( x,y,z ) \,dS = 8\int_0^{8} z\sqrt{1+4 z^2} \,dz=8\int_1^{257} \frac{u^{1/2}}{8} \,du = \frac{16}3\cdot\left(\frac{{257}^{3/2}-1}{8}\right)\approx 2746.02

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int\!\!\int_{S} \sqrt{ 1 + x^{2} + y^{2} } \: dS where S is the helicoid: \mathbf{r}(u, v) = u\cos(v)\mathbf{i} + u\sin(v)\mathbf{j} + v\mathbf{k}, with 0 \leq u \leq 4, 0 \leq v \leq 2\pi

Find \int_C\vec F\cdot d\vec r where C is a circle of radius 3 in the plane x+y+z=9, centered at (3,1,5) and oriented clockwise when viewed from the origin, if \vec F = 5y\vec i - x\vec j + 2\!\left(y-x\right)\vec k

static.solution: \mbox{curl }\vec F = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \vec i \amp \vec j \amp \vec k\\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\ \amp \ \frac{\partial}{\partial y} \ \amp \ \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\\ 5y \amp -x \amp 2\!\left(y-x\right) \end{array} \right| = 2\vec i + 2\vec j -6 \vec k, writing S for the disk in the plane enclosed by the circle, Stokes' Theorem gives \int_C\vec F\cdot d\vec r = \int_S\mbox{curl }\vec F\cdot d\vec A = \int_S(2\vec i + 2\vec j -6 \vec k)\cdot d\vec A. Now d\vec A = \vec n\,dA, where \vec n is the unit vector perpendicular to the plane and dA an area element on the plane, so \vec n = \frac1{\sqrt3}(\vec i + \vec j + \vec k), and \int_C\vec F\,d\vec r = \int_S(2\vec i+2\vec j -6\vec k)\cdot \frac{\vec i+\vec j+\vec k}{\sqrt{3}}\,dA = \int_S \frac{-2}{\sqrt 3}\,dA = \frac{-2}{\sqrt 3}\mbox{ Area of circle} = \frac{-18\pi}{\sqrt{3}}.

statement.p: Use Stokes' Theorem to evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{r} where \mathbf{F}(x, y, z) = x\mathbf{i} + y\mathbf{j} + 6\!(x^{2} + y^{2})\mathbf{k} and C is the boundary of the part of the paraboloid where z = 64 - x^{2} - y^{2} which lies above the xy-plane and C is oriented counterclockwise when viewed from above.

Verify the Divergence Theorem for the vector field and region:
\mathbf{F} = \left\lt 9x ,9z ,4y \right> and the region x^2+y^2\le 1, 0\le z \le 2

static.solution:
With z_0=2
Let \mathcal{S} be the surface of the cylinder and \mathcal{R} the region enclosed by \mathcal{S}.
We compute the two sides of the Divergence Theorem: \iint_{\mathcal{S}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} = \iiint_{\mathcal{R}} \text{div} (\mathbf{F}) \,dV We first calculate the surface integral.
Step 1. Integral over the side of the cylinder.
The side of the cylinder is parametrized by \Phi (\theta ,z)=(\cos \theta , \sin \theta ,z),\quad 0\le \theta \le 2\pi ,\quad 0\le z\le 2 \mathbf{n} = \left\lt \cos \theta , \sin \theta ,0 \right> Then, \mathbf{F} \left(\Phi (\theta ,z)\right)\cdot \mathbf{n} =\left\lt 9 \cos \theta ,9 z,4\sin \theta \right> \cdot \left\lt \cos \theta , \sin \theta ,0 \right>=9 \cos^2\theta +9 z \sin \theta We obtain the integral \iint_{\mathrm{side}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} = \int_0^{2} \int_0^{2\pi } \left(9 \cos^2\theta +9 z \sin \theta \right) \,d\theta \,dz=18 \int_0^{2\pi } \cos^2\theta \,d\theta +\left(\int_0^{2} 9 z \,dz\right)\left(\int_0^{2\pi } \sin \theta \,d\theta \right)=18\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{2}+\frac{\sin 2\theta }{4}\bigg|_0^{2\pi }\right)+0= 18\pi Step 2. Integral over the top of the cylinder.
The top of the cylinder is parametrized by \Phi(x,y)=(x,y,2) with parameter domain \mathcal{D}=\lbrace (x,y):\, x^2+ y^2\le 1\rbrace. The upward pointing normal is \mathbf{n} ={\mathbf{T} }_x \times {\mathbf{T} }_y = \left\lt 1,0,0 \right>\times \left\lt 0,1,0 \right> =\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{j} =\mathbf{k} = \left\lt 0,0,1 \right> Also, \mathbf{F} \left(\Phi (x,y)\right)\cdot \mathbf{n} = \left\lt 9 x,18,4 y \right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,1 \right>=4 y Hence, \iint_{\mathrm{top}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} =\iint_{\mathcal{D}} 4 y \,dA=0 The last integral is zero due to symmetry.
Step 3. Integral over the bottom of the cylinder.
We parametrize the bottom by \Phi (x,y)=(x,y,0),\quad (x,y)\in \mathcal{D} The downward pointing normal is \mathbf{n} = \left\lt 0,0,-1 \right>. Then \mathbf{F} \left(\Phi (x,y)\right)\cdot \mathbf{n} = \left\lt 9 x,0,4 y \right>\cdot \left\lt 0,0,-1 \right> =-4 y We obtain the following integral, which is zero due to symmetry: \iint_{\mathrm{bottom}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} =\iint_{\mathcal{D}} -4 y \,dA=0 Adding the integrals we get \iint_{\mathcal{S}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} =\iint_{\mathrm{side}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} +\iint_{\mathrm{top}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} +\iint_{\mathrm{bottom}} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} =18\pi +0+0=18\pi \quad\mathbf{(1)} Step 4. Compare with integral of divergence.
\text{div} (\mathbf{F} ) = \text{div} \left\lt 9 x,9 z,4 y \right>=\frac{\partial }{\partial x}(9 x)+\frac{\partial }{\partial y}(9 z)+\frac{\partial }{\partial z}(4 y)=9 \iiint_{\mathcal{R}} \text{div} \left(\mathbf{F} \right) \,dV = \iiint_{\mathcal{R}} 9 \,dV=9\iiint_{\mathcal{R}} \,dV=9\, \mathrm{Vol} (\mathcal{R}) = 9\cdot \pi \cdot 2=18\pi\quad\mathbf{(2)} The equality of \mathbf{(1)} and \mathbf{(2)} verifies the Divergence Theorem.
